messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Ted Larson Freeman"
<freeman@...> wrote:
>>>
>>>Could someone please point me to an example of the alternate letter
>>>for May? I can't find it in the QM...
>>>
>>
>> The May variation is implied on pg13 in the example for "mire" (and
>> elsewhere)
>
>Yes, I remembered that one. It hardly seems like an alternate letter
>form to me.
>

It is certainly less dramatic than the Utter variation. But there is
no way to use just one glyph and still produce something that looks
remotely like the QM example for "mire". A senior font creator must
make a separate glyph for it, a junior need not.


>>>...and I don't see it in any of the QS fonts...
>>>
>>
>> No font has ever been written to fully support QS. A few simulate a
>> super tight kerning which is not remotely the same thing (obviously).
>> Others include a few joined forms of vowel+Roe which has given rise
>>to the erroneous notion that these are ligatures.
>
>I realize that you're advocating a computational approach to Senior
>QS (good luck!) that goes far beyond current fonts, but why do you
>say that forms such as vowel+Roe are not ligatures?
>

I don't necessarily oppose ligaturing Utter+Roe, I only object to the
current reason for considering them a ligature. I would just observe that:

- Such a ligature is not necessary because Utter+Roe with tight
kerning look exactly like any ligature form of them I have ever seen.

- Read thought of them as Senior joins that should be learned early.
Thus his description of them is of an ordinary letter connection
not a ligature.

But if a graphic artist says they should be ligatured for aesthetic
reasons I would instantly defer to him/her. Similarly if something
resembling a ligature solves a serious problem (I believe the news
feed is testing this right now) then that too would be justification.
I just do not believe the QM describes them as ligatures or that Read
thought of them as such.

Conversely, it is overwhelmingly clear that Sea+Utter must be
ligatured in any Senior implementation: there is no possible way to
produce anything resembling the examples in the QM without doing so.
Yet this is hardly noticed because this didn't happen to get put in
the early fonts.


>>>Regarding the alternate letter for They, the QM only says "Letter
>>>No.8 may connect on the writing-line by an allowable extension
>>>upward and forward..." This is on page 13
>>>
>>
>> Which of course implies They has a variation. Unless of course
>>someone imagines this can be done by the rendering layer (fyi it
>>absolutely can not)
>
>My point here was simply that Read did not consider this variation to
>be an alternate letter.
>

I agree entirely, not an alternative letter; merely an alternative
glyph for that letter (I might argue he did think of them as
variations but avoided expounding on the examples in order to shorten
his pamphlet). But whatever Read's unstated intent, I suggest instead
what matters today is whether they must be treated as variations in
order for the system to work coherently. Obviously Junior can work
quite well without a They variation (or any variations for that
matter) but Senior is unworkable without them.

>>
>> The variations for No and Utter are mentioned in the senior section
>>of the QM. Junior has no more need for the alternative form of No or
>> Utter than it needs the alternative May or They.
>>
>
>Yes, but it's easy enough to include these in a list of QS
>letters--much easier than trying to enumerate letter connections.
>(See my next post.)
>

Very true but there is no reason to burden a Junior writer with the
alternate Utter or No because he can not use them. Nor is there any
reason for a Junior font to include them. And I do not immediately
know what is accomplished by a partial list of variations. Indeed, a
partial list will just confuse readers as they discover the unlisted
variations by reading the QM slowly.

>>
>> ... I've been avoiding the topic [senior unicode points] having
>>noticed that any proposal for completeness is futile.
>>
>
>I don't think it's futile at all--I just think you're the only one
>who's going to do it. If you do, many of us will be quite interested
>in what you produce.
>

It's probably my fault actually: it is just not possible to expound
these points with no images to point to and no implementation to refer
to. I'll try to remedy this and put something nice together.
